message: It's an honor to be sworn into the 115th Congress to continue serving #WI06. I'm so glad my family could be in D.C. today to stand by my side.

President-elect Trump was right to call out Big Pharma today for high drug prices and manufacturing practices that take place primarily outside of the U.S. My concerns include not only outrageous prices, but also overprescribing of opiates which leads to heroin addiction and overprescribing of medications to children for issues like ADHD and other related diagnoses.  Since my time in the Wisconsin State Legislature, I‚Äôve refused to take political donations from the pharmaceutical industry because of my belief that Big Pharma no longer prioritizes the creation of life-saving drugs over making money. I am pleased that the Trump administration will make driving down drug prices and bringing the pharmaceutical sector back to America a priority.
I spoke out against #Obamacare on the House floor this morning.
The Capitol is all dressed up and ready to go for #Inauguration2017.
Congratulations, President Trump! I look forward to working with you in the years ahead.

I wholeheartedly thank President Trump for his executive order today that allows for the construction of the Keystone XL pipeline. I‚Äôve been an advocate for the Keystone XL project since coming to Congress, and this just shows what can be done when we have a president who listens. This project provides an excellent opportunity to expand our local economies, improve our national infrastructure and invest in American workers.  It‚Äôs about time we had a president who looks out for American workers. This single act will reduce our dependence on foreign oil, lower gas prices and provide thousands of construction jobs. This executive order is part of an active first week for President Trump.
It was great to see President Trump today in Philadelphia during our Republican member retreat.

Today‚Äôs The March for Life is the perfect way to end this week of victories for the pro-life movement. I support the thousands marching on behalf of the unborn this afternoon.   I also want to thank Vice President Pence for attending the March for Life ‚Äì the first vice president to do so. The Trump Administration is already steering America back in a pro-life direction, and ensuring that our nation no longer disregards the rights of the unborn.

Friday‚Äôs executive order is just another example of President Trump fulfilling his campaign promises. Our focus, first and foremost, should be on defending America‚Äôs borders and keeping Americans safe.  It is important to specify that this is not a Muslim ban, as it has been widely misreported in the media. This executive order focuses only on improving our nation‚Äôs vetting process for those coming from areas of intensified conflict and with known terror groups attempting to infiltrate the U.S. through our refugee program.   This temporary ban allows the government time to review and update screening requirements to keep our citizens safe ‚Äì something that has become increasingly important as acts of terror happen more and more across the world.

I was elated to hear that President Trump picked Judge Neil Gorsuch as his Supreme Court nominee.  Gorsuch‚Äôs education and track record as a conservative voice on the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals in Colorado makes him a worthy choice to inherit the seat left by Justice Scalia.

I was honored to author this legislation alongside Senator Ron Johnson to authorize and request that the president award Fond du Lac native and WWII hero James "Maggie" Megellas with the Medal of Honor.

Yesterday, I spoke about the Social Security Fraud Prevention Act in House Oversight Committee. It prohibits agencies from including Social Security numbers on documents sent by mail.  The Internal Revenue Service has been sending Social Security information on postcards and in see-through envelopes, making identity theft easier. By preventing the transmission of such sensitive information by mail, we're protecting American families and seniors from the devastating and lasting impact of identity theft.

When I was a lawyer in the private sector, I was always frustrated when the government would take off for federal holidays while I was working.  For that reason, both my D.C. and Fond du Lac offices are open today. If you would like to contact us, please call 202-225-2476 (Washington, D.C.) or 920-907-0624 (Fond du Lac).
Thanks to Ripon College for having me on campus this morning to speak to its American Politics and Government class.

The anti-Semitic threats to Jewish communities across the U.S., and now close to home in Whitefish Bay, are unacceptable and abhorrent.   It‚Äôs  incredibly important for local law enforcement and the FBI to track these people down sooner rather than later.
While I'm at home, my office dog, Todd, is keeping my D.C. desk warm for me.
ICYMI- I weighed in on President Trump's first month during yesterday's UpFront with Mike Gousha.

I was honored to be at President Trump‚Äôs first address to a Joint Session of Congress.  He hit the right combination of outreach, optimism and hard-hitting realism as we look toward our country‚Äôs semiquincentennial.  President Trump encouraged the Senate to confirm a judge, Neil Gorsuch, whose principles reflect our Constitution. He laid out a future of taking our country‚Äôs best immigrants while remembering the victims of the failed immigration policies of our past. He promised to revitalize American industry, and has turned over a new leaf of the executive branch unabashedly praising law enforcement in our war against crime.  Additionally, he continued to rally Congress to repeal and replace Obamacare ‚Äì making it clear that Americans should be on the healthcare plans of their choosing, not ones forced on them by the federal government.   And as an added bonus for Wisconsin residents, President Trump mentioned our own Harley Davidson as a successful American business.  Overall, the agenda President Trump laid out tonight is one that will benefit all Americans. I hope that my colleagues on the other side of the aisle will work with congressional Republicans and this administration to help our country succeed.
I was honored to be named a Congressional Member of the Civil Air Patrol. It was great to see members of the Wisconsin Wing Civil Air Patrol in D.C. today.
I enjoyed sitting down with representatives of Wisconsin's The Y to discuss our state's YMCA programs.
I enjoyed reminiscing about my University of Wisconsin-Madison days with fellow Badgers at this morning's Wisconsin Alumni breakfast. Thanks for having me!

Congratulations to Sheboygan's own Acuity Insurance for being ranked #9 on FORTUNE 100 Best Companies to Work For.  Those in Wisconsin may know Acuity because it houses the country‚Äôs tallest flag pole outside its headquarters, but it also employees hundreds of Sixth District residents. Acuity is an exemplary organization and I‚Äôm proud it‚Äôs in Wisconsin.

Today I introduced a bill suspending U.S. Foreign Aid to countries that deny or delay accepting their criminal aliens that have been ordered removed from the United States.  The U.S. has tens of thousands of criminal immigrants that are ordered deported, yet their home countries refuse to take them back. Instead, these criminal immigrants are released back into the U.S., posing a dangerous threat to American citizens.  I find it appalling that we continue to send foreign aid dollars to countries that are actively putting Americans at risk by refusing to accept their criminal aliens, especially when our own country is so deeply in debt. My bill shifts our immigration system back in the right direction and halts America‚Äôs condoning of this bad behavior.
On March 11, WWII hero and Fond du Lac-native James "Maggie" Megellas turned 100. Today, we had a belated celebration with him in D.C. Happy birthday, Maggie!
On this day in 1854, the Republican Party was founded at the Little White Schoolhouse in Ripon.
Thank you to Maj. Gen. Dunbar for providing an update on the Wisconsin National Guard and its impact on our state.

Yesterday, I introduced a bill to eliminate work waivers for non-disabled, working age adults without dependents who receive food stamps.  Work requirement waivers are part of an unfortunate trend of government laws and regulations that create disincentives for individuals to work.This bill is an important step in reforming welfare programs to help free capable individuals from government dependence and empower them to achieve the American Dream.  Read more about the bill below:

I will be hosting a series of town hall meetings in the Sixth District on April 10th & 11th to hear your views on important issues, and to give you an update on what's happening in Congress.   Click the link below for all locations and times. I look forward to seeing you there!

It was wonderful to meet with the Wisconsin Cherry Blossom Princess, and Sheboygan native, Maria Giannopolous, as well as the Junior Cherry Blossom Princess, Carolyn.   The Cherry Blossom Princess Program is a cultural and educational experience for young women representing their respective states and territories. I'm proud to have these two young women representing Wisconsin!

This week‚Äôs chemical attacks in Syria were an atrocious act against the Syrian people and many innocent children. America needed to take action to stop any future attacks.   President Trump was right to take a strong stand in condemning the use of chemical weapons. I applaud our administration for holding Bashar al-Assad accountable.
Thank you to everyone who attended my town halls this week. I enjoyed engaging in conversation and answering your questions. It's an honor to serve as your representative in Congress.
Wishing you and your family a blessed and joyous Easter!
I hope you can join me tonight in Neenah for a town hall meeting. More info: http://grothman.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=298

The House just passed the Working Families Flexibility Act, a common-sense bill that allows private-sector employers to give hourly workers the option of either monetary compensation or additional paid time off for any overtime hours worked.  I was a proud co-sponsor of the bill, and I was proud to speak on the floor of the U.S. House of Representatives this afternoon in support of it.
We love our office dog, Todd! Find out more about him here:

FAFSA, the form all college students must submit if they are interested in receiving financial aid, recently experienced a data breach. The Department of Education and the IRS did not take action in a timely manner. The Department of Education refuses to recognize the data breach, and both agencies failed to report the breach to Congress within the required seven days.   Yesterday, in an Oversight and Government Reform Committee, I demanded answers: ‚ÄúIn my world, $30 million is a lot of money, and you all don‚Äôt seem to take it seriously at all. That is a result of your not taking action when a breach is made, and you‚Äôre not following the law to let Congress know. It‚Äôs so troubling to me that it takes so long for you to do anything.‚Äù

Obamacare is a proven disaster. Premiums have skyrocketed, quality of care has suffered and, more and more, Washington has exerted itself into what should be private, trusted doctor-patient relationships.  I voted for the new health care bill because the current system is unsustainable. Already, one-third of America‚Äôs counties only have one insurance provider, and the exchanges will continue to head towards disaster if Congress doesn‚Äôt act. Just yesterday, the last remaining insurer for the majority of the state of Iowa announced that it may drop off the exchanges ‚Äì leaving 94 of the 99 counties in the state without an insurance provider.   Quite simply, Americans deserve better.  This new bill still covers pre-existing conditions, while easing the burdens of Obamacare that have been forced onto so many of our families. With our vote today, the House has ensured that individuals and families will no longer be forced into expensive, inadequate Obamacare plans they do not want and cannot afford.

Under the AHCA:  -People cannot be kicked off current coverage or denied new coverage based on pre-existing conditions. -Members of Congress and our staffs are not exempt from the AHCA.  Get the facts at www.readthebill.gop.

Today is Teacher Appreciation Day. Thank you to all the teachers who helped me to get to where I am today, and to all the teachers in Wisconsin's Sixth District making a difference in the lives of our students every day.   One of my favorite parts of this job is meeting with educators and administrators. Aaron Sadoff is a former Manitowoc and Fond du Lac teacher who now serves as the superintendent for the School District of North Fond du Lac. I enjoy his visits to D.C.when he updates me on what's happening with educators in his school district.
Are you having trouble locating your important military records? My office can help you! To learn more about this and the other services my office can provide, please click the link below:
Happy Mother's Day to my mom, Joan. Thank you for your constant love and support.
Three great #WI06 businesses came by my office today. It was wonderful to meet with Mequon's Titan Spine, Fond du Lac's Mercury Marine and Sheboygan Falls' Johnsonville.

Career and Technical Education (CTE) helps to decrease student loan debt and provides students with real-world skills needed to compete for jobs that already exist in our local communities.  In Wisconsin, we have a great technical college system. By giving states more flexibility when using federal funds to support CTE programs, we can emulate Wisconsin's success across the country.  That's why I'm proud to co-sponsor the bipartisan Strengthening Career and Technical Education for the 21st Century Act. Read more below:
It's National Police Week! Let's honor and thank the men and women serving our communities as members of law enforcement.
For 50 years, Dutchland Plastics has provided quality jobs for members of our community. It's wonderful they're continuing this tradition and expanding in Wisconsin's Sixth District.
Congratulations to Rosendale's Mitchel Huff for achieving the rank of Eagle Scout this weekend!
From the Fond du Lac Greekfest to the Galloway House and Village Plant Sale, the Ozaukee County Sweat for Vets 5k, and several other events along the way, it was a busy weekend in #WI06.
I forgot my leather vest at home, but I still enjoyed having ABATE in the office to discuss issues affecting motorcycle riders.
Visiting D.C. this summer? Book a Capitol tour through my office: https://grothman.house.gov/forms/tourrequest/

Instead of emphasizing four-year college to all students, we should help young adults choose a path of higher education that best suits their needs while incurring the least amount of student debt.  Today, I questioned higher education experts on the value of four-year degrees for all students, and the importance of technical colleges and trade schools in reducing student loan debt.

This morning, I was shadowed by Katie Gordon, a former foster youth from Port Washington.   In recognition of Foster Care Month, Katie is raising awareness about the everyday challenges faced by foster youths in our community.  Since it was Katie‚Äôs first time in Washington, D.C., my staff and I gave her a behind-the-scenes tour of the Capitol building, sat in with her at a Budget Committee hearing and engaged in discussion about important foster care-related issues. #DCShadowDay #FosterYouthVoices

Wisconsin's unemployment rate keeps dropping - including in cities like Fond du Lac, Manitowoc, Neenah, Oshkosh and Sheboygan! Thank you, Governor Scott Walker, for keeping our state moving in the right direction.
Mike Rowe gets it.

This morning, I toured Hotel Retlaw in downtown Fond du Lac with the developers responsible for a $25 million renovation on the property. Once finished, the new Hotel Retlaw will be a wonderful boost for tourism in the area!
On Memorial Day, we remember the brave men and women who made the ultimate sacrifice for our freedom.
On this day in 1848, Wisconsin became the 30th state admitted to the Union. Happy birthday to our beautiful state! Ì†æÌ∑Ä

News of last night‚Äôs explosion at the Didion Milling plant in Cambria is devastating.   My thoughts and prayers are with the victims of this terrible incident, as well as the rescue crews that continue to work tirelessly.
Meet the newest member of Team Grothman! My deputy district director brought her daughter, Sophie,  by the office today.
This afternoon, I had the opportunity to picnic with RCS employees -- this is a great organization that helps individuals with special needs find employment in the private sector.
Seventy-three years ago, members of our Greatest Generation stormed the beaches of Normandy to preserve and protect freedom. Let us remember them this #DDay.
Six years after the failed and deadly Operation Fast and Furious, the Justice Department still hasn't provided Congress with all the information needed for the investigation into the scandal.
Dodd-Frank has created an environment in which local community banks are "too small to succeed". I was proud to vote for the Financial CHOICE Act today.

On Saturday, Vice President Pence visited Milwaukee to discuss repealing Obamacare.  In attendance was Allan Hibbard of Hibbard Financial in Manitowoc. Allan shared with the VP how his premiums have tripled from $5,000 to $15,000 under Obamacare.

President Trump will be in Wisconsin tomorrow to discuss the importance of career and technical education.  Read my op-ed in support of emphasizing the option of technical education to our young people.

Since Wisconsin's Sixth District has one of the highest numbers of manufacturers in the U.S., I was delighted to address the Industrial Truck Association today about safety in our factories, trade and vocational training.

As more news comes out about this morning's horrific shooting at the baseball field, I continue to think about my friend Congressman Steve Scalise.  My heart goes out to him, our brave Capitol Police officers and the other individuals who were injured today. I pray everyone makes a full recovery.
Did you know that the first-recognized celebration of Flag Day took place in Waubeka? I'm proud that Wisconsin's Sixth District is the birthplace of this American tradition.

"Today‚Äôs executive action by President Trump expanding our country‚Äôs apprenticeship program proves that the White House is willing to work with House Republicans to increase technical and vocational training, which will help fill vacant jobs and drive our economy.‚Äù
My staff enjoying the Congressional Baseball Game! Tonight, we're all #TeamScalise.
Happy Father's Day to my dad, Harold, and all the other dads out there. I hope you all have had a great day!

Glenn and Glen -- I was honored to stand with Glen, President and CEO of Manitowoc's Lakeside Foods, while I received the National Association of Manufacturers Award for Manufacturing Legislative Excellence.
Having an enjoyable evening with my mom and sisters at the White House Congressional Picnic!

Each month, an average of 214 churches and Christian properties are destroyed, 772 violent acts are committed against Christians and 322 Christians are killed because of their faith.  Today, I introduced a bipartisan resolution condemning the persecution of Christians across the globe. Read more at the link below:
Repealing the EPA's WOTUS rule will be a victory for farmers. The rule is federal overreach at its worst and hurts rural communities.

Two years ago, Kate Steinle was randomly gunned down in the sanctuary city of San Francisco by a criminal illegal immigrant with seven prior felony convictions and five deportations.   Today, I supported Kate's Law and the No Sanctuary for Criminals Act to ensure that no more Americans die because politicians refuse to enforce our immigration laws.
Congratulations to Sedona Spaeth of Two Rivers! She's WI-06's winner of the Congressional Art Competition. Her work is now on display in the U.S. Capitol.

241 years ago, our Founding Fathers adopted the Declaration of Independence and celebrated the birth of our great nation.   As we continue that celebration today, I hope you have a wonderful and safe 4th of July!

The current joint-employer standard leads to fewer small businesses and more lawyers.   In today's House Committee on Education and the Workforce hearing, I questioned small business executives and other employment experts about how joint employer hurts small businesses.

For years, the EPA has held Sheboygan County responsible for ozone pollutants that come from outside Wisconsin.   This "nonattainment designation" given to Sheboygan County hits existing manufacturers with penalties, and discourages new businesses and families from moving into the area.  I strongly encourage EPA Administrator Pruitt to work on resolving this injustice for the good of Sheboygan County and the state of Wisconsin.
Our troops deserve functional equipment, strong allies and financial security for their families. That's why I voted in favor of the NDAA for FY 2018.
Pierce Mfg, a subsidiary of Oshkosh Corporation, displayed one of its fire trucks at The White House this afternoon to kick off Made in America Week.

Bipartisan win! I joined Republican and Democrat Members of Congress in sending a letter President Trump asking him to delay lifting sanctions against Sudan. Last week, the president issued an executive order extending the sanctions review period.

From my op-ed in today's The Sheboygan Press: "For decades, Sheboygan County has been locked in a battle with the Environmental Protection Agency. The county has been unfairly, and incorrectly, held accountable for pollutants coming from outside Wisconsin." Read more below:

Just a reminder to please follow my social media policy, which is available in the "About" section of this page (and has been since I was elected to Congress), or risk getting blocked or removed from my social media:  Comments posted to this page will be monitored. Comments (i) containing obscene language or obscene sexual content, (ii) that promote illegal activity/transactions, (iii) that threaten any person or organization, (iv) that contain fighting words, (v) that imminently incite illegal activity, (vi) contain advertising or solicitation, (vii) endorse or disavow candidates for political office, (viii) are not topically related to the particular posting, and/or are (ix) postings related to campaign events or solicitations for any candidate will be removed and may result in the inability of the author to comment on any future posts.
It was wonderful to meet HUD Secretary Ben Carson this morning when he stopped by the House.

If you've called or visited the D.C. office this summer, you've probably talked to one of our three amazing interns. Thank you, Louisa, Lauren and Coco for all your hard work these past months! My staff and I are so grateful. Best of luck as you head home to Wisconsin and back to school.
Welcome to Wisconsin, Foxconn. This project is set to create 13,000 new jobs and transform the economy of our state.

"There are departments on major college campuses where you can spend all day walking up the hallways where the faculty work and never be exposed to anybody who voted for a candidate that about half of America's populace did. It's kind of amazing that you can find that lack of diversity anywhere."

My amendment to transfer funds to the Joint Light Tactical Vehicle (JLTV) program was included in the Department of Defense Appropriations Act that just passed the House.   The JLTV program will help save lives with its strong vehicle fleet and improve our troops‚Äô effectiveness in the field.

Earlier this week, I enjoyed dinner with my friends Rep. Lou Correa and Rep. Jimmy Panetta. We may have different ideas at times, but we still get along!
Any tax reform the House takes up should focus on benefiting the middle class.

Reince Priebus has been a friend and colleague for many years -- beginning with his run for the Wisconsin Legislature, and continuing to his time as chairman of the Republican Party of Wisconsin, the Republican National Committee and, most recently, as the White House Chief of Staff.   As RNC chair, he was incredibly successful, steering the Republican Party to more governorships, more seats in Congress and a Republican victory in the 2016 presidential election.   Because of Reince's leadership, Republican-elected officials are now in a position to return our country to its great state.   My friend Reince was a great pick to help lead the Trump administration over the past six months. I'm sad to see him go, and I thank him for serving his country so honorably. I look forward to working with him in some other capacity soon.

With more vitriol in politics and public discourse than ever before, my colleagues and I -- Democrats and Republicans --  have come together to sign a commitment to civility. We have different views across the political spectrum, but we all want to serve the American people to the best of our abilities.   Read more:
Such a neat experience touring the control tower at the EAA AirVenture and talking to air traffic controllers about FAA issues.

ICYMI... Grothman: White House shuffles not all bad. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really glad that Scaramucci is out, because he is not what we needed ‚Äî I think Gen. Kelly, given his background, you can‚Äôt help but be a little bit in awe of him, can you?‚Äù

My office is hosting a job fair on Thurs., Aug. 24, from 8:00 a.m.-2:00 p.m.   More than 30 businesses from across WI-06 will be in attendance to fill open positions in areas like engineering, welding and customer service.  For more information - including a list of participating businesses and open positions - and to RSVP, please click the link below. Hope to see you there!

In June, the Education and Workforce Subcommittee on Higher Education and Workforce Development held a hearing on the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act (WIOA), a well-meaning piece of legislation that experienced some hiccups during implementation under the Obama administration. Mainly, the Dept. of Ed. created a  list of factors that would disqualify an employer from being referred individuals with disabilities from state vocational rehabilitation services to fill a job.  What's resulted is a direct assault on the AbilityOne Program, which is the largest source of employment opportunities for people who are blind or have significant disabilities in the United States. Many of these positions and jobs are referred to 18-25-year-olds. As the AbilityOne Program is cut off, we see these young people left behind and let slip through the cracks.  After the hearing, I had the opportunity to meet Yael Kerzan of Pardeeville and her parents. Yael was born with Williams Syndrome, but that doesn‚Äôt stop her from working not one ‚Äì but two jobs at Walmart and Northwoods Incorporated of Wisconsin. Yael now advocates for others who can benefit from WIOA, specifically those young adults between 18 and 25.   Thanks to Yael and the Kerzan family for sharing their story, and being kind enough to send my office this video of their time in D.C.!

What's happening in Charlottesville is unacceptable, un-American and should not be tolerated. My prayers are with the victims of this weekend's violence.  http://www.cnn.com/2017/08/12/us/charlottesville-white-nationalists-rally/index.html

Due to the death of a member of Congressman Grothman's immediate family, the congressman's Mt. Calvary and Beaver Dam town halls will now be listening sessions with members of his staff.  Congressman Grothman will reschedule town halls in these locations for September.

My dad, Harold Warner Grothman, passed away on Tuesday, Aug. 22, 2017, at the age of 91. He was a loving husband to my mom, Joan, for 63 years, a caring father to his four children, a proud alumnus of the Badger Band and an American hero who served his country honorably in the U.S. Navy.  I will forever treasure the 62 years I spent with my dad. He instilled in me a love for country and Wisconsin, and never wavered in his support of his children as we pursued our dreams. He was one of my biggest cheerleaders throughout my career, and in life.  My dad was a wonderful man. I will miss him dearly. http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/jsonline/obituary.aspx?page=lifestory&pid=186466521

As storms continue to ravage the Gulf Coast and more hurricane damage becomes evident every day, my thoughts and prayers are with the victims.

I had the opportunity to meet with constituents at six town halls over the past three days. My office has taken her concerns very seriously, and I'm now communicating with the FDA on her behalf.   This is just one example of the type of casework my office handles. If you're having an issue with a federal agency, please contact my Fond du Lac office at (920) 907-0624. If you'd like to learn more about Dr. Rajamannan's concerns, please click the link below.

I joined nine other Republicans and 15 Democrats to cosponsor the Industrial Hemp Farming Act, which will legalize industrial hemp growing in the U.S.   Legalizing the growth of industrial hemp can only benefit farmers and manufacturers in Wisconsin and across the country. Read more below:

The news coming out of Las Vegas is horrific and devastating. My heart goes out to all those affected by this senseless act of violence.  If you need help locating a missing loved one in Las Vegas, please call 1-866-535-5654.

My office has been helping Sheboygan's Dr. Nalini Rajamannan for almost a year as she seeks answers from the FDA over faulty  heart valves. It was wonderful to finally meet her in person! Read her full story here: http://whbl.com/news/articles/2017/sep/14/interview-doctor-seeks-answers-from-fda-over-experimental-heart-valve/

Today I voted in favor of the bipartisan Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act to prevent late-term abortions on unborn babies who are capable of feeling pain. This bill is similar to Wisconsin's Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act, which was signed into law by Governor Scott Walker in 2015.

The National Labor Relations Board's (NLRB) caseload has decreased by 40 percent since 1980, but its funding has increased when adjusted for inflation.   In September I introduced an amendment to the appropriations bill that would have cut spending by making NLRB funding consistent with its current caseload. Unfortunately, my amendment failed, but I'm happy to see that it may have gotten the wheels turning on agency changes at the NLRB.
The House Committee on Education and the Workforce passed a bill to redefine the joint-employer standard and save small businesses. Find out more here:

My offices stay open on most federal holidays because it's simply not fair that your government isn't working when you are.  If you need to contact my D.C. or Fond du Lac office on Columbus Day, we'll be here to answer your calls. https://grothman.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=425
4 out of the top 8 Coolest Things Made in Wisconsin are made in the Sixth District (like Oshkosh JLTVs!). Vote for your favorite here: https://madeinwis.com/

In Wisconsin, we‚Äôre really good at making stuff. That‚Äôs what we do; especially in the Sixth District where 80,000 of our citizens wake up and go to work at factories and manufacturing facilities ‚Äì more than almost any other place in the country.   Wisconsin‚Äôs manufacturing industry keeps our state at the forefront of job creation and innovation.  To all those who work in manufacturing, I hope you have a wonderful National Manufacturing Day as you work hard to continue to grow the economy of Wisconsin.

My bipartisan resolution condemning the global persecution of Christians passed the House unanimously today. As Christians in the Middle East, Africa, Asia and the Americas are killed, abducted, trafficked and prevented from practicing their faith by extremist groups and government officials, this becomes a larger and larger global human rights issue.   H. Res. 407 calls for all discriminatory countries and extremist groups to cease their persecution of religious minorities and force leaders to uphold universal religious freedom.
Happy Hanukkah to all my friends in Wisconsin's Sixth District who begin their holiday celebration this evening!

"The freedom of religion is something we, as Americans, often take for granted. There are places around the world that today still discriminate, imprison, torture, and even kill others for their religious beliefs. Think of ISIS in the Middle East, Boko Haram in many parts of Africa, or even Kim Jong-Un in North Korea.  "And do you know which religion is suffering most in these places? It may surprise you that Christian persecution tops the charts in these nations...It is because of these stories, growing in number and breadth, that we affirm through H.Res 407, the Condemning the Persecution of Christians Around the World, that such persecution must cease."

While I sit on three committees in the House, many people don‚Äôt know that I‚Äôm also a member of several congressional caucuses and taskforces. These caucuses and taskforces are usually bipartisan, and focus on legislative priorities that center around a specific interest or cause. For the next few days, I‚Äôll highlight my caucuses. First up‚Ä¶ my religion-focused caucuses.  Yesterday, my bipartisan Christian persecution resolution passed the House, but that‚Äôs not the only way I‚Äôm defending freedom of religion at home and abroad; I‚Äôm also a member of four caucuses that focus on religious liberty:    ‚Ä¢ Bipartisan Taskforce for Combating Anti-Semitism ‚Äì to condemn anti-Semitism and spearhead initiatives that promote tolerance of the Jewish faith worldwide. ‚Ä¢ Bipartisan Congressional Ahmadiyya Muslim Caucus ‚Äì to highlight the religious and human rights abuses that the Ahmadiyya Muslim community faces every day. ‚Ä¢ International Religious Freedom Caucus ‚Äì to address religious persecution of people of all faiths or people of no faith. ‚Ä¢ Religious Minorities in the Middle East Caucus ‚Äì to serve as an advocate for religious minorities in the Middle East.

As I continue to highlight the caucuses I sit on, I'm focusing today on my international relations caucuses to build relationships between the U.S. and other countries: ‚Ä¢ Congressional Friends of Denmark Caucus ‚Ä¢ House Republican Israel Caucus ‚Ä¢ Dutch Congressional Caucus

Great news! The NLRB has overturned the Obama-era joint-employer standard that allowed businesses to be classified as a joint employer even if their relationships to employees were indirect.   In conjunction with a House bill we passed earlier this year overturning the standard, the NLRB has now ruled that a business must have direct and immediate control over employees to be considered a joint employer.

Wisconsin's Sixth District has more manufacturing jobs than almost any other place in the country. I'm proud of our strong manufacturing sector, and that we're so good at making stuff.  I've joined several caucuses in Congress that promote the manufacturing field that's so vital to Wisconsin's economy.

Today I'm focusing on agriculture-centered caucuses that emphasize how important agricultural products are to our country's economy.

I voted for the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act because  it will benefit Wisconsin taxpayers by modernizing the tax code, making America‚Äôs business climate more competitive and delivering tax relief to American families and workers.  I'm especially happy that this version of the bill focuses on the middle class and that the medical expense deduction has been reinstated.

Today I'm focusing on my caucus memberships that are related to healthcare, safety and chidcare.  I'm proud to support causes like adoption, preventing prescription drug abuse and heroin use, and the pro-life movement.
